user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_virt2phys:
```c
static int metal_virt2phys(void *addr, unsigned long *phys)
{
	off_t offset;
	uint64_t entry;
	int error;

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0)
		return -EINVAL;

	offset = ((uintptr_t)addr >> _metal.page_shift) * sizeof(entry);
	error = pread(_metal.pagemap_fd, &entry, sizeof(entry), offset);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed pagemap pread (offset %llx) - %s\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, strerror(errno));
		return -errno;
	}

	/* Check page present and not swapped. */
	if ((entry >> 62) != 2) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "pagemap page not present, %llx -> %llx\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, (unsigned long long)entry);
		return -ENOENT;
	}

	*phys = (entry & ((1ULL << 54) - 1)) << _metal.page_shift;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_virt2phys:
unsigned int page_shift
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed pagemap pread (offset %llx) - %s\n",		  (unsigned long long)offset, strerror(errno));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the code calls strerror(errno), which is declared in <string.h> but takes an int and returns a pointer to an internal static string. No pointer parameter to a string.h function is passed that could cause an out-of-bounds access. A concrete violation scenario would be if a buffer of insufficient size were passed to a copy function (e.g. strcpy(buf, some_string) where sizeof(buf) <= strlen(some_string)), or using memcpy/memmove with a length exceeding the destination object size.
